li.h1: The most advanced and dynamic dashboards and user interfaces for the highest quality of user experience

li.p:
Use our advanced dashboards to easily perform the best performance analysis.
More than simple dashboards, we provide rich, powerful and well designed user interfaces.
Dashboards and user interfaces are easily accessible from the application home page, we have a dashboard for all use cases.

ul.li:
Certified Technical Addon, low footprint and highly configurable
Our Technical Addons are heavily tested, qualified and certified against numbers of architectures and Operating Systems, this includes:
- IBM AIX 7.1 / 7.2
- PowerLinux Linux (RHEL/Ubuntu/SLES...)
- X86 (RHEL/Ubuntu/SLES...)
- Oracle Solaris 11 on X86 and SPARC
The Technical Addons are as well compatible with ARM platforms, IBM zLinux!

li.h1: Threshold management, frameID mapping and thresholds templating
li.h2: The alerting features implements a multi-layer thresholds system based on:
li.p:
- The frameID that allows logically grouping server assets
- FrameID mapping is achieved either at the raw level with different options (static definition, pre-ation scripts) or at search time with the KVstore management interface for frameID mapping
- Alerting thresholds values can be defined using macros default, on a per frameID template basis or on a per server basis using the KVstore collection management interfaces

li.h1: Builtin costs of ownership analytic and metrics volume optimizations
li.h2: Get the insight vision of every cost related to your deployment
li.p:
- The DCO dashboard provides you builtin analytic features against application costs, daily average volume and metric metadatas, and even more
- The Add-on dashboard provides automatic reporting your servers deployment, which versions are deployed on which servers
- Don't pay for a zero ! The Technical Addons have been slighty optimized to remove any useless data from the metrics generation, you only pay for what is useful

p.b: Nmon Analyser interfaces provides full reporting of almost every monitor available within the application and for the operating system concerned.
p.i:
Nmon Analyser interfaces have been designed for focused time ranges, very large time ranges may require time to be fully processed.
For long time analysis, please consider using metric dedicated interfaces available from App home pages

div.p:
NMON BASELINE interfaces provides an advanced system key metrics reporting to help detecting derivation anomalies based on past data history analysed and stored in KV stores.
The baseline is evaluated over a large dataset of past resources usage and allows determining if the current utilization level represents a potential derivation or normal conditions of use.
With the capacity of charting in the future, you can follow within the day resources usage and easily estimate what is probably not a normal situation for your specific system usage.

h4.i: Data Categories: Explore All / Event Types: nmon:performance (Performance data), nmon:config (Configuration data), nmon:collect (Nmon raw data generation), nmon:processing (Nmon raw data processing) - About Nmon Performance Monitor

div.div:
The Nmon application implements eventtypes to provide an easy and structured access to every piece of data within the app.
On the top most level, the main eventtype provides access to all raw data:

On sub-levels, Top interest eventtypes will contain the performance metrics data (nmon:performance) and configuration data (nmon:config) The nmon:collect eventtype contains information about nmon processes generation that will collect the performance and configuration data on servers. The nmon:processing eventtype contains information about processing steps that converts the nmon data into usable data for Splunk.

In the nmon:performance data, the "key" is the type field.
This field contains the monitor identifier that matches a category of metrics, such as "type=CPU_ALL". (global CPU usage in percentage)
For convenience, main monitors have been categorized into main eventtypes, but on the nmon:performance level any monitor can be filtered adding the "type=xxxx" search.
Note that searching for the CPU_ALL data for example, can be identically achieved by using "eventtype:nmon:performance type=CPU_ALL" or "eventtype:nmon:performance:cpu type=CPU_ALL".

The nmon:performance eventtype contains all the data related to performance metrics of your systems.
In the nmon:performance data, the "key" is the type field.
This field contains the monitor identifier that matches a category of metrics, such as "type=CPU_ALL". (global CPU usage in percentage)
For convenience, main monitors have been categorized into main eventtypes, but on the nmon:performance level any monitor can be filtered adding the "type=xxxx" search.
Note that searching for the CPU_ALL data for example, can be identically achieved by using "eventtype:nmon:performance type=CPU_ALL" or "eventtype:nmon:performance:cpu type=CPU_ALL".

The nmon:config eventtype contains all the data related to the configuration of your systems.
These are the AAA and BBB* sections of nmon raw data, generated during the nmon binary startup.
The events are long multi-lines events stored per host, in default configuration these data will be extracted almost every 2 hours as the data will not change unless a new nmon process gets launched.

The nmon:config data is associated with the generation of the nmon_inventory lookup and the Nmon_Config data model.
The nmon_inventory lookup table is being generated by a scheduled report (which runs by default every hour) that extracts main configuration items (number of CPUs, volume of physical memory...) from the nmon:configuration data over the Nmon_Config data model.
Once the nmon_inventory data has been generated, it is ready to be used and explored within various interfaces.

The nmon:collect eventtype contains all the data related to the nmon processes generation on your systems.
These are the ouput of the input script "nmon_helper.sh" thats gets automatically launched by Splunk when deploying the Nmon App.
By default, the nmon_helper.sh script gets started every minute, its main job is to verify the status of the current nmon process, and start a new one if conditions requires it.
Many nmon starting options can be controlled through the "nmon.conf" configuration file during the deployment of the App, get more information on the online Wiki:

The nmon:processing eventtype contains all the data related to the nmon processing steps that converts nmon data into usable data for Splunk.
These are the ouput of nmon2csv Python and Perl parsers provided within the App.
Every time an existing raw nmon file is updated, or a new one gets created, Splunk will call parsers scripts and generate appropriated data.
Many nmon starting options can be controlled through the "nmon.conf" configuration file during the deployment of the App, get more information on the online Wiki:

search.query: | `indexes_datestats` | eval summary='First Event' . " - " . 'Last Event' | fields summary

single.option: DATE OF FIRST AND LAST PERF EVENT

search.ref: Hosts with data within last 7 days

search.query: addinfo | eval time=strftime(_time, "%H%M"), lasttime=strftime(info_search_time, "%H%M") | where time<=lasttime | timechart span=1d sum(volume) as volume | where volume>0

search.ref: Number of notable events in Data Processing or Data Collect since last 24 Hours

drilldown.link: search?q=(eventtype=nmon:processing OR eventtype=nmon:collect error) OR (index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd ERROR ExecProcessor nmon) NOT ("There is no python in" OR "python: not found") earliest="-24h" latest="now"

search.ref: Volume of data indexed within last 7 days

span.title:
CPU Utilization statistics in Percentage (%)
• Represents the percentage of CPU system load for all available cores
• Statistics can be returned in global usage or main category: Sys,User,Wait,Idle

a.span: ALL OS: Percentage of CPU Utilization

span.title:
CPU Utilization per logical core statistics in Percentage (%)
• Represents the percentage of CPU system load by logical core (lower level of CPU usage details)
• Statistics can be returned in global usage or main category: Sys,User,Wait,Idle

a.span: ALL OS: Percentage of CPU Utilization per logical core

span.title:
IBM Power partitions statistics
• A Micro Power Partition (AIX or PowerLinux) returns various CPU utilization statistics in virtual CPUs units
• Additionnaly, the Partition is able to return statistics about the Pool that hosts the partition

a.span: AIX / PowerLinux: Virtual Partition and Pools CPU Utilization

div.p:
The LPAR monitor contains various CPU related metrics about Partitions and Pools utilization.
These metrics are available on AIX and PowerLinux partitions. (PowerLinux must run at least nmon 16e versions)
To be able to retrieve Pools related statistics, the partition must be authorized to do so in the HMC configuration for the Pseries.

span.title:
Virtual CPU Utilization of PSeries Pools (same as part of LPAR with some additional monitors)
• For IBM P5 generation and less, a Micro Partition that has App access will return the load of the PSeries
• For IBM P6 generation and more, a Micro Partition that has App access will return the load of it's Pool, and the load of the PSeries if it is part of the DefaultPool
CPU Utilization statistics in Percentage (%) for Workload Manager

div.p:
Workload Manager statistics for AIX and Solaris contains various performance metrics about Workload classes.
Depending on the operating system, this monitor includes CPU, Memory, Block I/O statistics.

span.title:
Statistics of Main Processes System Resources Usage
• Get the CPU core utilization of main processes aggregated by Command invocations
• Others Statistics available: Real/Virtual memory usage, minor and major faults and more
• With UARG information, filter PIDs from Command to get accurate measures of complex processes

a.span: ALL OS: Main Processes System Resources Usage

div.p:
The TOP monitor provides essential resource usage statistics of processes, and has specific interfaces per operating system.
Depending on the operating system, this monitor may include on a per process level CPU usage, Physical and Vitual memory usage, number of threads, Major and Minor faults...

span.title:
Search for PIDs, Commands and Full Arguments of Processes
• With UARG, get detailed information about Commands registered: PID, Full arguments and more
• These information can also be very useful within TOP interfaces for accurate analysis

a.span: ALL OS: Search for PIDs, Commands and Arguments

p.b: The UARG monitor provides PID information with full commands arguments, and has specific interfaces per operating system.

Nmon Baseline Analysis
• With the baseline Nmon KV Store, use this interface to analyse historical data and detect key system metrics derivations
• Key system metrics (CPU usage, Real and Virtual Memory, IOPS disk statistics) charted over the baseline
• Optionally chart current statistics over the future baseline and get realtime situation of system resources utilization

CPU Predictive Analysis Interface
• Using the predict Splunk command, this interface will help trying to estimate future load of your systems
• Choose between available algorithms: Local Level (LL), Seasonal Local Level (LLP), Local Level Trend (LLT) and LLP5 (combine LLT and LLP)

a.span: Predictive interface, forecast future using predict

span.title:
Nmon Comparison Interface
• Compare System Resources usage between 2 periods, a reference Period and arrival Period
• Choose between Main Monitors: CPU usage (CPU_ALL / LPAR), Memory, I/O, Network
• Evaluate the trend with Evolution Rate and graphical decorations to help instantly discover the comparison result

BubbleChart: TOP hosts CPU Usage
• Evaluate the TOP 100 hosts CPU load represented in Bubble Charts to instantly discover hosts responsible of the global load average
• Evaluate the TOP 20 hosts CPU load represented in d3chart bar chart
• Evaluate the full Statistics table of hosts CPU load with main hosts information

p.b: The TOP bubble chart dashboard provides a graphical view of TOP hosts using CPU, and has specific versions and/or options per operating system.
